commonScaffoldTanimoto(ScaffoldTree, ScaffoldTree) - Static method in class hier_scaffolds_utils
Returns similarity metric designed to reflect the significance of the maximum common scaffold between two molecules. Given by the formula:
  sim = nc / (na + nb - nc)
where
  nc = # atoms in common scaffold
  na = # atoms in max scaffold, mol A
  nb = # atoms in max scaffold, mol B
This is an experimental functionality. Intended for use in combination with a standard whole-molecule similarity metric.
commonScaffoldTanimoto(ScaffoldTree, ScaffoldTree, Scaffold) - Static method in class hier_scaffolds_utils
Returns similarity metric designed to reflect the significance of the maximum common scaffold between two molecules. Given by the formula:
  sim = nc / (na + nb - nc)
where
  nc = # atoms in common scaffold
  na = # atoms in max scaffold, mol A
  nb = # atoms in max scaffold, mol B
This is an experimental functionality. Intended for use in combination with a standard whole-molecule similarity metric. Use this faster method if mcScaf is already calculated (with maxCommonScaffold()).

F

findChildScaffold(Scaffold) - Method in class Scaffold
Search for child scaffold equal to the specified scaffold; if not found return null.
findChildScaffolds(Scaffold, ScaffoldSet, ScaffoldStore) - Static method in class hscaf_utils
This recursive algorithm finds all child scaffolds. For each junction bond, copy scaffold and cut bond, resulting in two parts which may be valid scaffolds (sidechains have been deleted, but one part may comprise invalid scaffold benzene). Special case is junction bonds to hydrogens, which denote attachment points. Then recurse and find grandchild scaffolds for each child scaffold. For simple 2-way linkers it is redundant to cut both junctions of a linker, but for (3+)-way linkers this allows enumeration of all combinations. For each scaffold found, if unique (via canonical smiles), add new child and specify its parentage. If no junction bonds exist, findChildScaffolds() returns null, recursion terminates, and the current scaffold is a leaf. The heavy-lifting goes through this method. ScaffoldSet and ScaffoldStore store known scaffolds to avoid costly re-analysis. With ScaffoldSet, if scaffold already known, use existing scaffold object, not new child candidate object. With ScaffoldStore, new object must be used.
findChildScaffolds() - Method in class Scaffold
This recursive algorithm finds all child scafs. For each junction bond, copy scaffold and cut bond, resulting in two parts which may be valid scaffolds (sidechains have been deleted, but one part may comprise invalid scaffold benzene). Special case is junction bonds to hydrogens, which denote attachment points. Then recurse and find grandchild scaffolds for each child scafs. For simple 2-way linkers it is redundant to cut both junctions of a linker, but for (3+)-way linkers this allows enumeration of all combinations. For each scaffold found, if unique (via canonical smiles), add new child and specify its parentage. If no junction bonds exist, findChildScaffolds() returns null, recursion terminates, and the current scaffold is a leaf.
This method does the heavy-lifting.
findScaffold(Scaffold) - Method in class ScaffoldSet
Return Scaffold with same cansmi, if present, otherwise null.

H

hier_scaffolds - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
HierS hierarchical scaffolds application. Run program with no args for command-line help.
For each molecule in the input dataset, scaffolds are perceived, including the hierarchical scaffold tree, and a set of unique scaffolds for the dataset is generated, with IDs assigned sequentially. The output molecule file is annotated with scaffold IDs. The output scaffold file is annotated with scaffold IDs and scaffold hierarchy tree (encoded as string)..
hier_scaffolds() - Constructor for class hier_scaffolds
 
hier_scaffolds_common - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
HierS hierarchical scaffolds application for max common scaffold search. Run program with no args for command-line help. Query input file is one molecule. Query is compared with each molecule from dataset input file, and common scaffolds are written to output. Also the scaffold-based Tanimoto similarity value is computed.
hier_scaffolds_common() - Constructor for class hier_scaffolds_common
 
hier_scaffolds_stats - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
HierS hierarchical scaffolds postprocess application. Run program with no args for command-line help. Key task is to generate scaffolds file annotated with occurance info including compound IDs.
Molecule files normally should be SMILES format. The SMILES "name" is a space delimited set of fields: (1) compound ID (integer), (2) set of scaffold IDs. For example: FC1=CC=C(NC2=NC(=NC3=CC=CC=C23)C2=CN=CC=C2)C=C1 1877191 S:4,5,6,17,18
Input scaffold file also normally SMILES, with "name" delimited set of fields: (1) scaffold ID, and (2) scaffold tree string. For example: N(C1=CC=NC=C1)C1=C2C=CC=CC2=NC(=N1)C1=COC=C1 35 35:(38:(5,6),6,36:(5,37),37)
hier_scaffolds_stats() - Constructor for class hier_scaffolds_stats
 
hier_scaffolds_utils - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
Contains static functions used in hierarchical scaffold analysis. These public API functions for use in applications.
hscaf_utils - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
Contains internal static functions used in hierarchical scaffold analysis. Not normally recommended for use by applications.

mergeScaffoldTree(Scaffold) - Method in class ScaffoldDB
Merges a fully populated ScaffoldTree defined by the Scaffold argument with the ScaffoldDB. New scaffolds are assigned new IDs. Existing scaffolds are recognized as such. Initially called with new root scaffold, then recursively. For each call, process all immediate child scaffolds, then assign ChildIDs and ParentID to ScaffoldRecord. Note that a new unknown parent may have known and/or new child scaffolds. Hence this recursive method must handle the known-scaffold case.
mergeScaffoldTree(Scaffold) - Method in class ScaffoldSet
Merges a complete [sub]ScaffoldTree defined by the Scaffold argument with the ScaffoldSet. New scaffolds are assigned new IDs, which is the main purpose of this method. Existing scaffolds are recognized as such, should have IDs, since found during hscaf_utils.findChildScaffolds. Initially called with new root scaffold, then recursively. For each call, process all immediate child scaffolds, then recurse. Child scaffolds present in set are same instances, not only equal. Returns number of new scaffolds merged.
mergeScaffoldTree(Scaffold) - Method in class ScaffoldStore
Merges a fully populated ScaffoldTree defined by the Scaffold argument with the ScaffoldStore. New scaffolds are assigned new IDs. Existing scaffolds are recognized as such. Initially called with new root scaffold, then recursively. For each call, process all immediate child scaffolds, then assign ChildIds and ParentId to ScaffoldEntity. Note that a new unknown parent may have known and/or new child scaffolds. Hence this recursive method must handle the known-scaffold case.
minDist(int, int) - Method in class ShortestPath
Gets the length of the shortest path between two nodes of the graph.

rmPart(Molecule, String) - Static method in class hscaf_utils

rmSideChains(Molecule, boolean) - Static method in class hscaf_utils
Remove side chains leaving only scaffold. Removes, iteratively, terminal atom by terminal atom. Scaffolds and linkers should include atoms multiply-bonded to the scaffold or linker. Arguably the algorithm used here involving smarts is a kludge, and should simply rely on the junction bonds and atoms to figure out which atoms to remove. However, I currently do not see how to do that, since, for example, a given atom might need removal if part of a "dangling" linker, but not if the linker is involved in the scaffold. Maybe the tagJunctions() method should also annotate all atoms as scaffold, linker or sidechain.

S

Scaffold - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
Represents any single HierS scaffold, which may contain zero, or two or more child scaffolds. A scaffold with zero child scaffolds is called a leaf scaffold. Each scaffold has a unique set of child scaffolds. However, a scaffold may have multiple parent scaffolds, in a scaffold tree context or a scaffold database context, since the same scaffold may be present in multiple locations within one molecule or multiple molecules. The largest scaffold of a molecule is the root scaffold (a.k.a. the Bemis-Murko framework). For a single molecule a related set of Scaffold objects represents the HierS scaffold hierarchy; similarly a scaffold hierarchy can be defined for a database. Scaffolds are by default non-stereo but may be stereo.
Scaffold(Molecule, boolean, boolean) - Constructor for class Scaffold
When initialized from a molecule, sidechains are removed and explicit hydrogens are added at each junction bond. If molecule has no rings, return empty scaffold.
Scaffold(String, Boolean, Boolean) - Constructor for class Scaffold
Initialized molecule from smiles and call usual constructor.
Scaffold(Scaffold) - Constructor for class Scaffold
Copy constructor.
scaffoldByCanSmi - Variable in class ScaffoldStore
 
scaffoldById - Variable in class ScaffoldStore
 
scaffoldCansmi2ID(String) - Method in class ScaffoldDB
 
ScaffoldDB - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
Provides persistent scaffold storage via standard RDB. For large jobs this avoids memory limits and improves performance by storing solved scaffolds for rapid lookup and avoiding re-calculation.
An additional benefit of DB usage is paralellization, since separate processes can concurrently read and write to the same scaffold database by locking and unlocking records.
Minimal, standard RDB features required; no chemical cartridge used, smiles canonicalization by client.
PostgreSQL supported only. Maybe should use another layer to be database agnostic (support MySql, etc).
ScaffoldDB(String, int, String, String, String, String, String, Boolean, Boolean, Boolean) - Constructor for class ScaffoldDB
Constructor creates or opens existing database at location specified.
ScaffoldEntity - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
Scaffold entity used for storage in BerkeleyDB-based ScaffoldStore.
Developer note: Auto-sequencing did not work correctly for cases where a database was re-opened, which resulted in skipping ahead (to nearest largest multiple of 100). So scaffold IDs are manually assigned 1 + count().
ScaffoldEntity(Long, String) - Constructor for class ScaffoldEntity

ScaffoldSet - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
Represents a set of unique HierS scaffolds . Purpose of this class is to Store set of scaffolds, compactly, generated for input molecular dataset, for output . Optimize generation of scaffolds by avoiding repitition of prior analyses. IDs are consecutive and start at 1. Child scaffolds are not separate instances but rather among the set and may be shared. Developer note: scafhash and idhash contain references to the same Scaffold objects, thereby conserving memory.
Note that the ScaffoldStore class is an alternative utilizing BerkeleyDB for improved performance and memory management for large datasets.
ScaffoldSet() - Constructor for class ScaffoldSet
Default constructor.
ScaffoldSet(String) - Constructor for class ScaffoldSet
Constructor with name.
ScaffoldStore - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
Initiate and provide local storage & retrieval via BerkeleyDB. For large jobs this avoids memory limits and improves performance by storing solved scaffolds for rapid lookup and avoiding re-calculation.
Note that ScaffoldSet is an alternative for in-memory storage, for if BerkeleyDB is unavailable or for small datasets.
For largest jobs use ScaffoldDB (PostgreSQL).
ScaffoldStore(File, Boolean, Boolean) - Constructor for class ScaffoldStore
Constructor creates or opens existing database in directory specified. Tuning and configuration would be addressed here.
ScaffoldTree - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
Comprised of a set of hierarchical scaffolds each a Scaffold object. Each input molecule has an associated ScaffoldTree, a hierarchical tree of Scaffolds, the largest of which is the root scaffold (and the Bemis-Murko framework). The ScaffoldTree object does not contain the Scaffold objects, which may be contained in a ScaffoldSet or re-constructed from ScaffoldStore ScaffoldEntitys. The ScaffoldTree object also contains the Linkers and Sidechains for the input molecule, and a copy of the input molecule.
[Implementation notes] Here are the steps in perceiving the scaffolds of an input molecule: ScaffoldTree constructor called by application with input molecule as parameter, and either a ScaffoldSet, ScaffoldStore or ScaffoldDB instance, which stores known scaffolds, for output to unique list, and to avoid re-analysis of previously encountered scaffolds, and thereby enhance performance. The application may elect to use ScaffoldStore, which uses BerkeleyDB, for large-ish datasets. ScaffoldSet in-memory storage is faster for small datasetsbut may exhaust available memory for large datasets. For large (> 100k compounds) jobs, or for directly populating a database, ScaffoldDB can be used, but requires an available database server. For each input molecule, a complete ScaffoldTree is built. When ScaffoldSet is used, the ScaffoldTree references Scaffold instances which are contained in the ScaffoldSet. When ScaffoldStore is used, all Scaffold instances must be re-constructed from ScaffoldEntity objects. When ScaffoldDB is used, all Scaffold instances must be re-constructed from ScaffoldRecord objects. The perception of scaffolds from a molecule is accomplished by: hscaf_utils.tagJunctions() - tags junction bonds hscaf_utils.findChildScaffolds() - breaks one junction bond, then analyzes each part as candidate scaffold, then recurse for each part until no more junctions.
ScaffoldTree(Molecule, boolean, boolean, ScaffoldSet, ScaffoldStore, ScaffoldDB) - Constructor for class ScaffoldTree
Create ScaffoldTree by analyzing input molecule. All scaffolds will be found and associated with the root scaffold, a.k.a. the Bemis-Murko framework. If input molecule is multi-fragment, throw exception. Either (1) ScaffoldSet, (2) ScaffoldStore, or (3) ScaffoldDB used as a lookup to avoid re-analysis of previously analyzed scaffolds.
ScaffoldTree(Molecule, boolean, boolean, ScaffoldSet) - Constructor for class ScaffoldTree
ScaffoldSet used for storage.
ScaffoldTree(Molecule, boolean, boolean, ScaffoldStore) - Constructor for class ScaffoldTree
ScaffoldStore used for storage.
ScaffoldTree(Molecule, boolean, boolean, ScaffoldDB) - Constructor for class ScaffoldTree
ScaffoldDB used for storage.
ScaffoldTree(Molecule, boolean, boolean) - Constructor for class ScaffoldTree
No ScaffoldStore, no ScaffoldSet, no ScaffoldDB.

ShortestPath - Class in edu.unm.health.biocomp.hscaf
The ShortestPath class calculates and stores the length of shortest paths between any two nodes of a molecular graph. The implementation is based on the Floyd-Warshall algorithm. One instance of ShortestPath can be reused to compute distances for several chemical graphs, this serves the more efficient storage space usage. Internal structures are grown dynamically when a molecular structure larger than any previous one is given as input for the shortest path calculation. (Author: Miklos Vargyas, ChemAxon)
ShortestPath() - Constructor for class ShortestPath
Creates a new ShortestPath object.

SubMatchMap(Molecule, Molecule) - Static method in class hier_scaffolds_utils

For convenience depicting molecules with highlighted atoms corresponding to a scaffold.
subTreeAsString() - Method in class Scaffold
Generates string representing the hierarchical scaffold sub tree rooted by this scaffold. e.g. "1:(2,3)" or "1:(2:(3,4,5),6:(4,7))"

T

tagAllRoles(Molecule, ArrayList<Integer>) - Static method in class hscaf_utils
EXPERIMENTAL***************** Called after tagJunctions, tags every atom identifying it as scaffold, linker, or sidechain. Note that sidechains may be joined to scaffolds or linkers.
Contains experimental code in development not yet utilized, eventually to improve efficiency and reduce reliance on smarts patterns.
tagJunctions(Molecule, boolean) - Static method in class hscaf_utils
Tag junction bonds joining scafs, linkers and sidechains, using MolBond.setSetseq(). Set to unique connection ID >1. Not tagged are junctions connecting linkers and sidechains.
